pr_title: [BEAM-10557] Implemented SchemaIOProvider for DataStoreV1, Refactored tests

timeline.message: Implemented SchemaIOProvider for DataStoreV1, refactored tests

timeline.bodyText:

timeline.author: TheNeuralBit

timeline.author: TheNeuralBit

timeline.bodyText: Will this work if we just use STRING? (Rather than re-creating CalciteUtils.CHAR here)
timeline.author: TheNeuralBit
TheNeuralBit

timeline.bodyText: I think you could just re-use provider here and in the other tests. If you're worried about re-using the same instance in all the tests you could consider initializing provider in an @Before method instead of initializing statically so that each test will get a fresh instance.
timeline.author: TheNeuralBit

timeline.bodyText: I think it would be better to get rid of this function and call provider.configurationSchema() instead.
timeline.author: TheNeuralBit

timeline.bodyText:
I think we're now preferring to use withFieldValue rather than addValue when constructing Row instances now, e.g.: Row.withSchema(provider.configurationSchema()).withFieldValue("keyField", "field_name") See the examples in Row.java: beam/sdks/java/core/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/values/Row.java Lines 64 to 74 in 956e4eb *

There are several ways to build a new Row object. To build a row from scratch using a schema * object, {@link Row#withSchema} can be used. Schema fields can be specified by name, and nested * fields can be specified using the field selection syntax. For example: * * 

{@code 
        

        
          
            * Row row = Row.withSchema(schema) 
        

        
          
            *              .withFieldValue("userId", "user1) 
        

        
          
            *              .withFieldValue("location.city", "seattle") 
        

        
          
            *              .withFieldValue("location.state", "wa") 
        

        
          
            *              .build(); 
        

        
          
            * }
timeline.author: TheNeuralBit

timeline.bodyText:
Let's describe the configuration parameters here. Something like this (spotless probably has an opinion on how this should be formatted): Suggested change /** * Returns the expected schema of the configuration object. Note this is distinct from the schema * of the data source itself. */ /** * Returns the expected schema of the configuration object. Note this is distinct from the schema * of the data source itself. * *

Configuration Parameters: *

    *
  • STRING keyField: The name of the Beam schema field to map the DataStore entity key. Defaults to {@code __key__} if not set or null. *
*/
timeline.author: TheNeuralBit

timeline.bodyText:
I don't think this new method is actually called anywhere. Should it be called from SchemaIOTableWrapper#getTableStatistics?
It might also be good to just get rid of the other getTableStatistics and move the default implementation to this one.
timeline.author: TheNeuralBit

replies.bodyText: The reason why I added this additional getTableStatistics() function was that DataStoreV1 is the first IO whose getTableStatistics() function relied on the schemaIO data, and this SchemaIOTableWrapper#getTableStatistics function could be overridden in DataStoreV1TableProvider. The other IOs so far have not required the schemaIO. Do you think we should get rid of the other getTableStatistics() function and always require a schemaIO, even when the schemaIO isn't absolutely necessary? Or support both cases?
replies.author: sclukas77

replies.bodyText: I see what you mean now. I got rid of the old getTableStatistics() function and moved the default implementation to this one.
replies.author: sclukas77
